experiments.title: To verify the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in an electrical circuit, as expressed by Ohm's Law: V=IRV = IRV=IR
experiments.objective: To verify the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in an electrical circuit, as expressed by Ohm's Law: V = IR

circuit_setup: Connect the resistor in series with the ammeter to measure current.
Connect the power supply in series with the resistor, and connect the voltmeter across the resistor to measure voltage.
initial_settings: Set the power supply to a low voltage value (e.g., 1V).
Ensure the power supply is set to provide a constant voltage.
measurement: Record the initial voltage across the resistor using the voltmeter and the current through the circuit using the ammeter.
Incrementally increase the voltage output from the power supply in small steps (e.g., 1V).
For each increment, measure and record the voltage and current.
Repeat this process at least 5-10 times for accuracy.
analysis: Plot a graph of voltage (y-axis) vs. current (x-axis).
The slope of the line represents the resistance (R) of the resistor: R = V / I.
The slope should remain constant, confirming Ohm's Law.

experiments.title: To apply Kirchhoff’s Voltage Law (KVL) and Kirchhoff’s Current Law (KCL) to analyze and validate simple electrical circuits.
experiments.objective: To apply Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL) and Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) to analyze and validate simple electrical circuits.

KVL_Circuit: Construct a series circuit with two resistors and the power supply.
Use the voltmeter to measure voltage across each resistor.
Connect the ammeter in series to measure current.
KCL_Circuit: Construct a parallel circuit with two resistors and the power supply.
Split the current into two branches: one through each resistor.

measurement: For the series circuit, measure and record the voltage across each resistor and the total current.
For the parallel circuit, measure and record the current in each branch.
Verify that the sum of the currents entering the junction equals the sum of the currents leaving the junction.
analysis: Apply Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL): ∑ I_in = ∑ I_out.
Confirm that measurements adhere to KVL and KCL.
Discuss conservation of charge (KCL) and energy conservation (KVL).

experiments.title: To study the behavior of resistors in series and parallel configurations, including the equivalent resistance calculation.
experiments.objective: To study the behavior of resistors in series and parallel configurations, including the equivalent resistance calculation.

series_circuit: Connect the three resistors in series with the power supply.
Measure the total voltage across the series combination using the voltmeter.
Record the current through the circuit using the ammeter.
parallel_circuit: Connect the three resistors in parallel with the power supply.
Measure the voltage across each resistor using the voltmeter.
Measure the total current supplied by the power supply.
calculation: For the series circuit, calculate total resistance: R_total = R_1 + R_2 + R_3.
For the parallel circuit, calculate equivalent resistance: 1/R_total = 1/R_1 + 1/R_2 + 1/R_3.
Verify calculated values with measured voltage and current.
analysis: Compare theoretical and measured resistance values.
Discuss how current behaves in series vs. parallel circuits.

experiments.title: To study the forward and reverse bias characteristics of a PN junction diode.
experiments.objective: To study the forward and reverse bias characteristics of a PN junction diode.

forward_bias: Connect the diode in series with a resistor and the power supply, ensuring that the anode is connected to the positive terminal.
Gradually increase the supply voltage from 0V and measure the voltage across the diode and the current through the circuit at each step.
reverse_bias: Reverse the diode’s orientation, connecting the anode to the negative terminal of the power supply.
Gradually increase the reverse voltage and measure the voltage across the diode and the current through the circuit.
analysis: The forward characteristic curve should show a sharp increase in current once the diode reaches its threshold voltage (~0.7V for silicon diodes).
In reverse bias, the current should remain negligible until the breakdown voltage is reached.

experiments.title: To analyze voltage regulation using a Zener diode.
experiments.objective: To analyze voltage regulation using a Zener diode.
materials: Zener Diode (with known breakdown voltage, e.g., 5.1V)

circuit_setup: Connect the Zener diode in reverse bias across the power supply, in series with the resistor.
Ensure correct orientation for reverse bias.
input_voltage_increase: Gradually increase the input voltage and measure the voltage across the Zener diode.
observation: Once the input voltage exceeds the Zener breakdown voltage, observe stabilization of the voltage across the Zener diode.
Measure and record the voltage and current at various points as the input voltage increases.
analysis: Confirm that the voltage across the Zener diode remains relatively constant above the breakdown voltage, demonstrating its voltage regulation capability.
Discuss applications of Zener diodes in voltage regulation and protection circuits.

experiments.title: To construct and analyze the performance of half-wave and full-wave rectifiers, both with and without filters.
experiments.objective: To construct and analyze the performance of half-wave and full-wave rectifiers, both with and without filters.

half_wave_rectifier: Connect a single diode in series with the load resistor and the secondary winding of the transformer.
Apply an AC input and measure the output waveform using an oscilloscope.
Add a capacitor in parallel to the load resistor to form a filter and observe the changes in the output waveform.
full_wave_rectifier: Construct a bridge rectifier circuit using four diodes.
Connect the bridge to the transformer and load resistor.
Measure the output waveform using the oscilloscope.
Add a filter capacitor to smooth the output waveform and observe the effect.

experiments.title: To analyze and implement wave-shaping circuits using diodes for clipping and clamping applications.
experiments.objective: To analyze and implement wave-shaping circuits using diodes for clipping and clamping applications.

clipping_circuit: Construct a series clipping circuit with a diode and resistor in series with the input signal from the function generator.
Observe and record the output waveform using the oscilloscope, noting the clipped portions.
clamping_circuit: Construct a clamping circuit by connecting a diode, capacitor, and resistor in the appropriate configuration.
Observe and record the output waveform, noting any shifts in the DC level.

experiments.title: To analyze the input and output characteristics of Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJTs) and Field-Effect Transistors (FETs).
experiments.objective: To analyze the input and output characteristics of Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJTs) and Field-Effect Transistors (FETs).

input_characteristics_bjt: Set up the circuit with the BJT in common-emitter configuration.
Vary the base-emitter voltage (VBE) using the DC power supply and measure the base current (IB) for different collector-emitter voltages (VCE).
Record the data at multiple values of VCE and plot the IB vs. VBE characteristic curve.
output_characteristics_bjt: Set IB to a constant value and vary VCE.
Measure the collector current (IC) for each VCE and plot the IC vs. VCE curve.
From the output curve, identify the active region, cutoff region, and saturation region of the transistor.

transfer_characteristics_fet: Set up the circuit with the FET in common-source configuration.
Vary the gate-source voltage (VGS) and measure the drain current (ID).
Plot the ID vs. VGS curve to observe the characteristics of the FET.
output_characteristics_fet: Set VGS to a constant value and vary the drain-source voltage (VDS).
Measure the drain current (ID) for different values of VDS and plot the ID vs. VDS curve.
Identify the linear and saturation regions from the graph.

experiments.title: To design a common emitter amplifier and analyze its frequency response.
experiments.objective: To design a common emitter amplifier and analyze its frequency response.

Circuit Design: Calculate the biasing resistors to set the desired operating point (Q-point) for the transistor.
Choose appropriate values for the collector and emitter resistors to set the gain and stability of the amplifier.
Select coupling capacitors (e.g., 10µF) for input and output to block DC and pass the AC signals.
Select a bypass capacitor (e.g., 100µF) across the emitter resistor to stabilize the frequency response.
Circuit Assembly: Assemble the circuit on the breadboard, connecting all components according to the designed schematic.
Connect the function generator to the input through the coupling capacitor.
Connect the oscilloscope to the output through another coupling capacitor.
Use the oscilloscope to monitor the output signal.
Frequency Response Analysis: Apply a sinusoidal input signal of constant amplitude.
Sweep the input frequency across the desired range (e.g., 10Hz to 1MHz) using the function generator.
Measure and record the output amplitude at each frequency using the oscilloscope.
Plot the gain (Vout/Vin) versus frequency to observe the frequency response.
Identify the cutoff frequencies (lower and upper) where the gain starts to drop significantly.
Analysis: The frequency response graph should exhibit a flat region at mid frequencies, with a roll-off at both high and low frequencies.
Discuss the bandwidth of the amplifier and its gain at different frequencies.
Explore the use of the common emitter amplifier in various applications such as audio amplification.

experiments.title: To implement and analyze operational amplifier (Op-Amp) circuits: inverting, non-inverting, summing, and differentiator configurations.
experiments.objective: To implement and analyze operational amplifier (Op-Amp) circuits: inverting, non-inverting, summing, and differentiator configurations.
Materials: Operational Amplifier IC (e.g., LM741 or equivalent)

Inverting Amplifier: Connect the non-inverting input (+) to the ground.
Connect the inverting input (-) to the input signal through a resistor (Rin).
Place a feedback resistor (Rf) between the output and the inverting input.
Apply a sinusoidal input signal and observe the output.
Verify that the output is inverted and calculate the gain as -Rf/Rin.
Non-Inverting Amplifier: Connect the non-inverting input (+) to the input signal.
Connect the inverting input (-) to the ground through a resistor (Rg).
Place a feedback resistor (Rf) between the output and the inverting input.
Apply a sinusoidal input signal and observe the output.
Verify that the output is in phase with the input and calculate the gain as 1 + (Rf/Rg).
Summing Amplifier: For an inverting summing amplifier, connect multiple input signals to the inverting input (-) through individual resistors.
Connect the non-inverting input (+) to the ground.
Place a feedback resistor (Rf) between the output and the inverting input.
Apply multiple input signals and observe the output.
Verify that the output is the inverted sum of the inputs, calculated as -Rf/Ri1 - Rf/Ri2 - ... for each input Ri.
Differentiator: Connect a capacitor between the inverting input (-) and the input signal source.
Place a resistor (R) between the output and the inverting input (-).
Connect the non-inverting input (+) to ground.
Apply a triangular or square wave input signal and observe the output.
Verify that the output is proportional to the derivative of the input, with the gain determined by R and C as -RdC.

experiments.title: To verify the operation of basic logic gates: AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR, and XNOR
experiments.objective: To verify the operation of basic logic gates: AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR, and XNOR.

procedure.name: Setup and Testing
steps: For each gate, apply all possible input combinations (e.g., 00, 01, 10, 11 for two-input gates).
Observe and record the output for each combination.
Compare the observed outputs with the expected outputs according to the respective truth tables of the gates.

experiments.title: To investigate the charging and discharging behavior of a capacitor in an RC circuit and understand the time constant.
experiments.objective: To investigate the charging and discharging behavior of a capacitor in an RC circuit and understand the time constant.
materials: Function Generator (optional for generating square wave)

procedure.name: Circuit Setup
steps: Connect the resistor in series with the capacitor and the power supply to form an RC circuit.
Connect the voltmeter across the capacitor to measure the voltage during charging and discharging.
Optionally, use the function generator to provide a square wave input to the circuit.

procedure.name: Charging the Capacitor
steps: Connect the power supply to the circuit and start with the capacitor uncharged.
Turn on the power supply, and record the voltage across the capacitor at regular intervals.
Observe how the voltage rises over time according to the equation: V(t)=Vmax(1−e−t/RC)
Plot the voltage vs. time graph. The curve should resemble an exponential rise.

procedure.name: Discharging the Capacitor
steps: Disconnect the power supply and let the capacitor discharge through the resistor.
Record the voltage across the capacitor at regular intervals during the discharging process.
The voltage should follow the equation: V(t)=V0e−t/RC
Plot the discharging curve and observe the exponential decay.

experiments.title: To investigate the resonance behavior of an LC circuit and measure the resonant frequency.
experiments.objective: To investigate the resonance behavior of an LC circuit and measure the resonant frequency.

procedure.name: Circuit Setup
steps: Connect the inductor and capacitor in series to form an LC circuit.
Connect the function generator to provide a variable frequency signal to the circuit.
Use the oscilloscope to measure the voltage across the capacitor.

procedure.name: Resonance
steps: Start with the function generator at a low frequency and gradually increase the frequency.
Observe the voltage across the capacitor on the oscilloscope.
At a certain frequency, the voltage across the capacitor will increase significantly, indicating resonance.
Measure the resonant frequency f0f_0f0​, given by: f0=12πLCf_0 = 1/(2 π sqrt{LC})f0=2πLCD1​​

experiments.title: To calibrate an oscilloscope for accurate measurements of voltage and time.
experiments.objective: To calibrate an oscilloscope for accurate measurements of voltage and time.

procedure.name: Setup
steps: Connect the function generator to the oscilloscope input.
Set the function generator to output a sine wave with a known frequency and amplitude (e.g., 1kHz and 1V peak-to-peak).

procedure.name: Voltage Calibration
steps: Measure the amplitude of the sine wave on the oscilloscope.
Compare the reading with the function generator’s set value.
Adjust the oscilloscope’s vertical scale (V/div) until the waveform is clearly visible and accurately scaled.

procedure.name: Time Calibration
steps: Set the function generator to output a square wave at a known frequency (e.g., 1kHz).
Adjust the oscilloscope’s time scale (s/div) to measure one complete cycle of the square wave.
Verify that the period matches the inverse of the frequency.

experiments.title: To determine the turns ratio of a transformer and verify the relationship between the primary and secondary voltages.
experiments.objective: To determine the turns ratio of a transformer and verify the relationship between the primary and secondary voltages.

setup: Connect the primary coil of the transformer to the AC power supply.
Connect the secondary coil to a load resistor and measure the secondary voltage using the voltmeter.
measurement: Measure the input (primary) voltage V1V_1V1​ and the output (secondary) voltage V2V_2V2​.
Calculate the turns ratio n=N1N2n = \frac{N_1}{N_2}n=N2​N1​​, where N1N_1N1​ is the number of turns on the primary coil and N2N_2N2​ is the number of turns on the secondary coil.

experiments.title: To construct and analyze a bridge rectifier circuit and compare its performance with a half-wave rectifier.
experiments.objective: To construct and analyze a bridge rectifier circuit and compare its performance with a half-wave rectifier.

circuit_setup: Construct a bridge rectifier circuit using four diodes in a bridge configuration.
Connect the AC supply to the bridge rectifier and the resistor to the output.
Use the oscilloscope to measure the output waveform.

experiments.title: To study the frequency response of a low-pass filter and determine its cutoff frequency.
experiments.objective: To study the frequency response of a low-pass filter and determine its cutoff frequency.

circuit_setup: Connect the resistor and capacitor in series to form an RC low-pass filter.
Connect the input signal (from the function generator) to the input of the filter.
Connect the output of the filter to the oscilloscope.
frequency_sweep: Apply a sinusoidal input signal and vary the frequency using the function generator.
Measure the output amplitude at each frequency using the oscilloscope.
Record the frequency at which the output voltage decreases by 3dB (the cutoff frequency).

experiments.title: To measure the input and output impedances of an operational amplifier (Op-Amp) in a given configuration.
experiments.objective: To measure the input and output impedances of an operational amplifier (Op-Amp) in a given configuration.

circuit_setup: Set up the Op-Amp in an inverting or non-inverting amplifier configuration.
Use the function generator to apply a sinusoidal signal to the input.
Measure the output signal with the oscilloscope.
input_impedance_measurement: Connect a known resistor in series with the input signal.
Measure the voltage across the resistor and the input voltage using the oscilloscope.
Calculate the input impedance using the formula: Zin=VinIinZ_{\text{in}} = \frac{V_{\text{in}}}{I_{\text{in}}}Zin​=Iin​Vin​​
output_impedance_measurement: Apply a load resistor to the output of the Op-Amp.
Measure the voltage across the load resistor and calculate the output impedance using: Zout=VoutIoutZ_{\text{out}} = \frac{V_{\text{out}}}{I_{\text{out}}}Zout​=Iout​Vout​​

experiments.title: To generate and analyze Lissajous figures using an oscilloscope by applying two sinusoidal signals with different frequencies.
experiments.objective: To generate and analyze Lissajous figures using an oscilloscope by applying two sinusoidal signals with different frequencies.

setup: Connect the two channels of the oscilloscope to the output of the function generator.
Set the function generator to produce two sine waves of different frequencies (e.g., f1=1kHzf_1 = 1kHzf1​=1kHz, f2=2kHzf_2 = 2kHzf2​=2kHz).
display_lissajous_figures: Apply the two sine waves to the two channels of the oscilloscope.
Observe the Lissajous figures formed on the oscilloscope screen. These figures will depend on the frequency ratio between the two signals.
Vary the frequencies and amplitudes of the signals and observe how the Lissajous figures change.

experiments.title: To study the magnetic field produced by a solenoid and verify the relationship between current and magnetic field strength.
experiments.objective: To study the magnetic field produced by a solenoid and verify the relationship between current and magnetic field strength.

setup: Connect the solenoid to the DC power supply, ensuring the current is adjustable.
Place a compass at various positions around the solenoid to measure the direction and strength of the magnetic field.
measurement: Vary the current supplied to the solenoid and observe the effect on the magnetic field.
Use the galvanometer to measure the induced current when the solenoid is placed in a changing magnetic field.
